docs.lead_paragraph: A lesbian congresswoman tests the soil in Wisconsin.
docs.abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column contends that Rep Tammy Baldwin of Wisconsin stands a good chance of becoming the first openly gay or lesbian person elected to the United States Senate in November; argues that many Wisconsinites seem unconcerned about her sexual orientation, trend that mirrors increased national acceptance of homosexuality.
docs.snippet: A lesbian congresswoman tests the soil in Wisconsin....

docs.lead_paragraph: AS computers become indispensable to modern life, the steepest learning curve society faces is not technical but philosophical. It is easy enough to learn, like a lab rat, to click a simulated button in a Web browser and download the patterns of symbols called computer programs. In a matter of seconds you are the proud owner of a new word processor, calculator or computer game -- an invisible, virtual machine. Far more difficult is coming to grips with the nature of so intangible a possession. Throughout the world of the Internet, people who would never think of stealing a cellphone or a camera find it easy to justify downloading pirated software. For all the work that goes into designing these digital creations, they just don't quite seem like real things.
docs.abstract: People throughout world of Internet who would never think of stealing cellphone or camera find it easy to justify downloading pirated software; federal investigators have recently raided campuses and high-tech companies across country, seizing computers and hard drives, evidence against what they say is is one of largest software piracy rings; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine that there's anything cutting-edge about this hardscrabble town on the Philippine island of Mindanao, which is best known for the ferocity of its various antigovernment insurgencies. But just off the main road, down a dusty alleyway and past the naked children and the few stray dogs at play, Melanie Pico sits in her tidy, modest home acting out one of the hottest trends in global finance and development theory. She is an entrepreneurial client of a microfinancing organization. She looked up from her sewing machine to rattle off the arithmetic of her life. She clears 1 peso and 80 centavos in profit -- about 3 American pennies -- for each market shopping bag she produces from recycled cement wrapping. If the back pain doesn't get to be too much and she can sit at her machine for 16 hours in a day, she can stitch together as many as 420 bags. Her hard work brings in, on average, 3,000 pesos a week, the equivalent of nearly $60, a princely sum in a region where many farmers make do on a dollar a day.
docs.abstract: Editorial Observer column by Andres Martinez on how microfinancing can alter lives of poor women around world; describes woman in Mindanao in Philippines who was able to start her small business with mere $60 loan from local microfinancing organization that promises clients 'hand up, not a hand-out'; notes that microfinancing is grass-roots development tool that works best when run as viable business, independent of government; says prospective borrowers in Mindanao must sit through 10 hours of rudimentary business training, and must pay interest on their loans; says challenge for outfits like Asian Development Bank and Inter-American Development Bank, and for government policy makers everywhere, is to find ways to help speed transfer of funds to remote villages at lower cost and provide pool of working capital for microfinancing

headline.main: Editorial Observer; How a Seed-Money Loan of $60 Turned Melanie Pico Into an Entrepreneur

docs.lead_paragraph: A SURPRISE blockbuster often has a way of unsuspectingly crystallizing a mood that makes it a must-see film, even if it isn't very good. Conversely, what is touted as a likely hit can end up an unexpected flop if it seems somehow out of touch. ''Meet the Parents,'' this fall's runaway hit, and ''Almost Famous,'' its sorriest box-office disappointment, have been the season's big surprises in Hollywood. If their wildly different moods are any measure of their commercial allure, then anger, sourness, paranoia and a sense of powerlessness (''Meet the Parents'') have trumped idealism, nostalgia and rock 'n' roll dreams (''Almost Famous''). What was once hip is now square.
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden article on movies as mirrors of cultural mood comments on nihilistic comedy Meet the Parents, which mined vein of outrage to beome this fall's runaway hit, and softly nostalgic Almost Famous, which flopped at box office (M)
